title: Heartbroken mum used a Find My Phone app to discover teenage daughter's body
text:

A devastated mum discovered her missing daughter's body using a Find My Phone app, an inquest heard.

Tragic Abi Oliver, 18, was found hanging in a West London park.

The teenager had told her mum she was going out to meet friends when she took her own life.

Abi had struggled with mental health problems for several years, and spent a year in hospital after taking an overdose.

Her family had raised concerns that the vulnerable teen was moved hundreds of miles away to a psychiatric unit in Manchester during her treatment due to a lack of beds available.

(Image: Hounslow Chronicle)

She was unable to see friends or relatives for six months after she was moved from a previous London hospital where she received visits on a daily basis.

The family raised further concerns about the guidelines in place for patients transitioning from child to adult mental health care units and said he did not want more children to fall into a “black hole” in the system.

Friends and family rallied together to search for Abi when she failed to return home and they used the Find my Phone app which traced GPS signals from her mobile phone.

Her mum administered CPR before Met Police, London Ambulance Service and London Fire Brigade arrived.

(Image: Universal Images Group via Getty)

But they were unable to save Abi and she died at West Middlesex Hospital in January last year.

In a statement read aloud to West London Coroners' Court her mum Tasha said: “I was happy that Abi had made plans to meet with friends on her own as Abi had been suffering with long term depression and anxiety.

“She spent a year in four different hospital after taking an overdose.

“Abi planning to meet a friend was good because she would not even go to the shops with me.”

Abi told her mum she would cut through the grounds of Chiswick House and the pair walked their separate ways.

But her mum became concerned when Abi failed to return home and she received no reply when she texted her to say “are you okay? Love mum.”

A small search party rallied together to look for the 18-year-old who was found in a west London park using the Find my Phone app which traced the GPS signals from her mobile phone.

In her statement, Tasha said: “I returned home at around 5pm. Abi was not home.

“I was unsure how long to leave her. I did not want to pressure her. I even text my friend asking how long to leave it.

“I went outside to look for her as I was concerned I had not heard from her. The Find my Phone app, it initially showed her close to the school.

“I zoomed in on the map and it showed Abi being in the grounds of Chiswick House.”

The inquest was told the teen had left a suicide note.

Abi’s mother said: “There is a problem with adolescent mental health, the progression to adult services and their care in hospitals.”

Coroner Sean Cummings said he is may contact the government regarding potential improvements for mental health services for young people after Abi’s family raised concerns.

He said: “I am going to consider whether it would be useful for me to report to the secretary of state in terms of provisions of mental health for young people.”

Coroner Cummings said Abi’s file was one of the most distressing he has seen and confirmed her death as suicide.

He said: “When I read the file, it was one of the more distressing files I have read.

“This has been the inquest of Abigail Frankie Oliver who died on January 27, 2018 at West Middlesex University Hospital.

“My conclusion is that Abi died as a result of suicide.”

With reference to the suicide note left by Abi before she died, the coroner added: “In much the same was as you have told me she was loved, she loved her family too."
